title: 107_hr4513
content: The Act is titled the "Social Security Number Protection Act of 2002" and includes findings. The Congress finds that the sale or purchase of Social Security numbers contributes to illegal activities like fraud and identity theft, posing risks to individual privacy. The Federal Government mandates Social Security numbers for tax purposes, benefits eligibility, and employment. The Federal Government mandates Social Security numbers for tax purposes, benefits eligibility, and employment. However, the unintended consequence is that these numbers can be used for crime and fraud, leading to privacy invasions. It is necessary for the Government to take action to prevent abuse of the system. The sale of Social Security numbers should be restricted to protect individuals from harm and unlawful conduct. Congress should enact legislation to offer necessary protection in such circumstances. The sale of Social Security numbers should be restricted to prevent unlawful conduct and unfair practices. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Commission" refers to the Federal Trade Commission, "person" means any individual or entity, "sale" involves exchanging a Social Security number for value excluding government benefit applications, and "purchase" is defined as providing something in exchange. The term "purchase" is defined as providing anything of value in exchange for a Social Security number, excluding government benefit applications. The terms "Social Security number" and "Social Security account number" have specific meanings as defined in the Social Security Act. The term "State" includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Northern Mariana Islands, the United States Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, and any U.S. territory or possession. SEC. 4. REGULATION OF THE SALE AND PURCHASE OF SOCIAL SECURITY NUMBERS AND SOCIAL SECURITY ACCOUNT NUMBERS. The regulation prohibits the sale or purchase of Social Security numbers in violation of Commission regulations. The Commission will create restrictions on the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers and account numbers, consulting with relevant agencies. Restrictions and conditions will be imposed on these transactions. The regulations will impose restrictions on the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers to prevent fraud and harm to individuals. Exceptions will be included in the regulations. Exceptions in the regulations allow the sale and purchase of Social Security numbers for law enforcement, national security, public health, emergency situations, and research with safeguards against misuse. The researcher must ensure that any information about identifiable individuals obtained from the research will not be used to make decisions affecting specific individuals, and appropriate safeguards are in place to protect privacy and confidentiality. The Commission must promulgate regulations within one year of the enactment of the Act, in accordance with section 553 of title 5, United States Code. The regulations and related sections will take effect 30 days after being published in the Federal Register. Enforcement actions will be taken for any violations of the regulations. The Commission must enforce regulations under the Act, treating violations as unfair or deceptive acts under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Any violators will face penalties and be subject to the same enforcement as the FTC Act. The Act incorporates privileges and immunities from the Federal Trade Commission Act. States can take civil actions on behalf of residents for violations of Commission regulations. The Act allows states to bring civil actions in federal court to enjoin acts, enforce regulations, obtain damages, or seek other legal relief on behalf of residents. Before filing an action, the state's attorney general must provide notice to the Commission and the Attorney General. The Act allows states to bring civil actions in federal court to enforce regulations or seek legal relief. Before filing, the state attorney general must notify the Commission and Attorney General, who have the right to intervene or stay the action. The Act allows states to bring civil actions in federal court to enforce regulations or seek legal relief. State attorney generals must notify the Commission and Attorney General before filing, who have the right to intervene or stay the action. During pending criminal proceedings, no State may bring an action under this section against any defendant named in the criminal proceeding or civil action for any violation alleged in that proceeding. The Act allows states to bring civil actions in federal court to enforce regulations or seek legal relief. State attorney generals have powers to conduct investigations, administer oaths, compel witnesses, and produce evidence. Actions can be brought in any district court meeting venue requirements. Process can be served in any district where the defendant is located.
